page.title: 15Power: Electricity/Gas
page.content: {Electricity and gas} are the commonest forms of power in homes and industries. Electricity is produced in {power stations} where water is boiled to produce steam which is forced through turbines which rotate very quickly to allow electricity to be generated. The electricity is then conducted along overhead cables to homes and industries. Most {power staions} burn coal to boil the water, but oil and nuclear power are also used. Most of the gas that we use is {natural gas} from under the north sea. This is sent along underground pipes to homes and industries where it is used as a source of heat for various jobs. Unlike electricity it is possible to store gas in gasometers until it is required. Both gas and electricity pass through a metering device which records how much has been used.
